blog.name: jeremy-ken-anderson
blog.title: In Which I Write

summary: Look for Bias Within
title: Look for Bias Within
body:
So the other day I saw a review of Captain Marvel in which they said the character just didn’t have - their literal quote - “that 'spark’ you see in a lot of the other super heroes in the MCU.”

Insert bad joke about how she literally glows. Moving on.

And it strikes me that there is a higher standard to hold critics to when they’re talking about marginalized groups.
Like, I don’t think this statement would have annoyed me if it were talking about Ant-man or even Star Lord. I’d disagree about Star Lord’s portrayal, but I wouldn’t be offended by the poor expression.

I AM offended that this critic didn’t bother to cite problems with the performance. Like, how fucking convenient that Brie Larson lacks a quoi that you je n’ais se, rather than having a substantive flaw that could actually be proven or disproven. And in spite of this, that it’s presented as fact (”she lacks that spark”) rather than opinion (”I didn’t enjoy her performance”).

I think this guy was trying, at the very least, to appear unbiased about the film, but every critique was a statement of certainty about something being good or bad with no example of what made him think that. What he does include is a clearly false assertion that she gets/delivers “no good lines” in the film, which is just…

“I have nothing to prove to you.”

“Don’t make me do this!” “Okay.” <(This is one of my favorite exchanges in the whole movie and the delivery is outstanding)

“I’ve been fighting with one arm tied behind my back. But what happens when I’m finally set free?”

Carol has LOADS of good lines, powerful lines about taking back who you are from people who demand you act subservient. And Brie Larson delivers them really well. For her good lines not to read as good lines, you’d have to think a woman finding her power isn’t coo-

Ohhhhhhh

It’s tempting to say the guy’s just a raving misogynist and write him off, but I doubt it. It’s far more likely that he’s trying to write a nuanced review, failed a bit at citing sources, and most importantly let his own biases drive the conversation rather than catching them and pushing back.
It’s possible that “the spark” as this guy sees it is the presence of a dick and he really is arguing a moderate dislike of this huge blockbuster only because hard dislike wouldn’t be believable enough to his fanbase. But there’s another option that’s more charitable to his morals:

It’s possible that “the spark” is part acting chops and part relatability, and there are a lot of scenes that are simply more commonly feminine interactions. If you’re a man, a lot of them haven’t happened to you. Maybe you’ve heard about them happening to a female friend? But those scenes won’t resonate with you personally, if they haven’t happened to you or at least in your presence and meant something at the time.
That, in turn, reduces your empathy for her in other scenes, and if you’re also having trouble grappling with the fact that she is - in spite of being beautiful - not treated as a sexual object by the camera even once in the entire movie? This gets mixed up into a Hidden Bias Smoothie, a fundamental sense of not liking her as much as other superheroes for…reasons. And then you’re writing reviews in an environment where the raving misogynist reviewers are getting called out and looking stupid because the movie’s doing great, but something doesn’t sit right with you about the movie and the process of sussing out why would require asking yourself some hard fucking questions.

So you don’t. You just say she lacks a “spark.”

summary: Captain Marvel Breakout Lashana Lynch Is Ready to Take Flight
title: Captain Marvel Breakout Lashana Lynch Is Ready to Take Flight
excerpt: The actress behind Maria Rambeau reflects on playing a new kind of character in the M.C.U.
description:
After a handful of parts in British films and TV, Lynch got her big American break via a Shonda Rhimes–produced take on Romeo called Still Star-Crossed. Lynch played the show’s leading lady and Romeo’s first love, Rosaline. Though short-lived, the ABC period drama introduced Lynch to Rhimes, and set her up for what could prove her star-making run—first saving the world from an alien apocalypse in Captain Marvel and, soon, surviving a different apocalypse as Agent 355, the female lead of FX’s Y: The Last Man, the long-anticipated adaptation of Brian K. Vaughan’s comic.

Oh. Oh. Huh.

reblog.comment:

Vaughan’s comic.

Oh. Oh. Huh.

Vaughan’s comic.

blog.name: loveandsupportforcaptainmarvel
blog.title: Captain Marvel Doesn't Care For Your Sexism
blog.description: Blog dedicated to standing up to the hate directed at Captain Marvel

summary: I think one of my favorite moments in Captain Marvel was when Yon-Rogg, a white guy, was yelling at Carol and challenging her to...
body: I think one of my favorite moments in Captain Marvel was when Yon-Rogg, a white guy, was yelling at Carol and challenging her to control her emotions, all while she was standing there nice and calm. If that isn’t a perfect reflection of how White Boys have reacted to this movie, I don’t know what is.

reblog.comment: I think one of my favorite moments in Captain Marvel was when Yon-Rogg, a white guy, was yelling at Carol and challenging her to control her emotions, all while she was standing there nice and calm. If that isn’t a perfect reflection of how White Boys have reacted to this movie, I don’t know what is.

trail.content_raw: I think one of my favorite moments in Captain Marvel was when Yon-Rogg, a white guy, was yelling at Carol and challenging her to control her emotions, all while she was standing there nice and calm. If that isn’t a perfect reflection of how White Boys have reacted to this movie, I don’t know what is.
trail.content: I think one of my favorite moments in Captain Marvel was when Yon-Rogg, a white guy, was yelling at Carol and challenging her to control her emotions, all while she was standing there nice and calm. If that isn’t a perfect reflection of how White Boys have reacted to this movie, I don’t know what is.

blog.description: Sara | British 🇬🇧 | 26 | TS Butterfly | "I'm selfish, impatient and a little insecure. I make mistakes, I am out of control and at times hard to handle, but if you can't handle me at my worst, then you sure as hell don't deserve me at my best." Disney, Marvel, Harry Potter, Star Wars. Other stuff. Mainly that stuff though.

tags: and it came in a really cool envelope
i cant wait to add more tickets!!!
summary:
The hat is not only super stylish but it’s also super comfortable!!!
And don’t even get me started on the lithograph. It’s...
body:
My Captain Marvel hat and lithograph just came in and I’m LIVING!

The hat is not only super stylish but it’s also super comfortable!!!

And don’t even get me started on the lithograph. It’s STUNNING.

I framed it and put a few of the tickets I managed to keep inside with it. I’ll be going to see it again soon so I’ll have to put more tickets in it.

I really love this!!!

blog.name: ellasrandomrambles
blog.title: Ella's Random Rambles
blog.description: Ella– 21 years old, Capricorn, Airbender, ENFP, Hufflepuff

summary: So after watching Captain Marvel...
body:
So after watching Captain Marvel…

I got really inspired by Brie Larson and how great she looked in that movie. It made me want to be a strong badass too. So I’ve been slowly working at it.

I’ve been going on walks around my neighborhood. And my dad said that I probably walked about a quarter of a mile. And I was so sad knowing that I could barely walk a quarter of a mile without almost dying. Like how unfit am I!?! Turns out… ITS 2.1 MILES!!!

I’ve been walking 2.1 miles everyday thinking that it was only a quarter of a mile!! Thinking that I should be able to do more.. well I was doing a lot more than I thought. And I’m proud of myself…. and I cant wait to rub it in my dads face lololol

reblog.comment:
So after watching Captain Marvel…

I got really inspired by Brie Larson and how great she looked in that movie. It made me want to be a strong badass too. So I’ve been slowly working at it.

I’ve been going on walks around my neighborhood. And my dad said that I probably walked about a quarter of a mile. And I was so sad knowing that I could barely walk a quarter of a mile without almost dying. Like how unfit am I!?! Turns out… ITS 2.1 MILES!!!

I’ve been walking 2.1 miles everyday thinking that it was only a quarter of a mile!! Thinking that I should be able to do more.. well I was doing a lot more than I thought. And I’m proud of myself…. and I cant wait to rub it in my dads face lololol

blog.name: loveandsupportforcaptainmarvel
blog.title: Captain Marvel Doesn't Care For Your Sexism
blog.description: Blog dedicated to standing up to the hate directed at Captain Marvel

summary: Everyone who thinks Steve won’t like Carol because he’ll be jealous of her captain title or he’ll think she’s trying to replace...
body: Everyone who thinks Steve won’t like Carol because he’ll be jealous of her captain title or he’ll think she’s trying to replace him is weak. Steve adores powerful women, he worships them. You disappoint Captain America.

reblog.comment: Everyone who thinks Steve won’t like Carol because he’ll be jealous of her captain title or he’ll think she’s trying to replace him is weak. Steve adores powerful women, he worships them. You disappoint Captain America.
